messages: 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (01:56): hm, how do we solve the gmail problem of not being able to use real links because of Referer? use a new attribute <a secrethref="">?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:57): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: maybe just a noreferrer attribute?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:57): I would guess only <a> needs it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:57): and <img>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:57): for <script> or <img> it could be a security issue to skip referrer
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (01:58): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: but then legacy UAs would still send the Referer
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:58): for <img> you clearly don't want it, since it would make hotlinking undetectable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:58): <img> in an HTML e-mail shouldn't send Referer headers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:58): (welcome to conflicting requirements)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:58): <img> to an external resource in HTML e-mail shouldn't display by default, and possibly not at all
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:59): just pinging the server back at all is a privacy concern
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:59): not by default, sure
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:59): Referer doesn't really add much privacy violation beyond just loading the <img>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:59): depends what's in the url

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:01): put it this way, someone who isn't out to violate your privacy would likely embed the image rather than making it an external reference, since in most mail clients these days you have to go out of your way to do the latter;  and if they are out to violate your privacy, they could do much worse by careful URL design than with Referer
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:02): i don't deny any of that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:02): i'm just saying there are also requests for not passing referrers for <img>s
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:02): whether we satisfy those requests or not is another question
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:02): <a>link text <href>http://...</href></a> -- that would be backwards compatible
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:03): kinda
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:03): you could script that for legacy UAs to fake the link
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:04): or just leave it and let the user copy the URL
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:04): you could script the other one too
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:04): yeah, but the user wouldn't know the URL without script
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:06): how does gmail handle links in its "html basic" version?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:06): no i mean <a href="..." noreferer> could be scripted
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:06): dunno, try it
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:06): yeah but then legacy UA would still send Referer... isn't that an issue?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:08): gmail html basic has plain links
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:08): <a href="..." target="_blank">
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: so i guess at least for gmail it's not an issue
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:16): yeah
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:20): <input title="name"type="text"> that fails wcag 2.0 because of lack of whitespace between the attributes
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:21): see 4.1.1 in http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:29): search for "SCR24: Using script to open a new window" to find the accessible version of target="_blank"
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:32): font-size must also be specified with %, apparently
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:33): or am i misreading the document? the next technique contradicts that
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:34): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: wait, why is that an accessibility issue?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:35): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: because ie6 can't change the text size if you specify "absolute" units
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:35): not the % thing, the lack of whitespace between attributes
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:36): yeah, dunno
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:36): the document also says that <p>foo<p>bar</p> in XHTML is a fail, because it is "unclear" whether the second paragraph is a child or a sibling to the first
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:46): so they're assuming XHTML will be processed with an error-correcting html parser?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:46): i have no clue
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:47): in html, it is not unclear at all. in xml, it's not unclear at all either
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:47): it's unclear if you don't know what parser will be used
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:47): but then they could just say that
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:47): indeed
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (02:49): if that's what they meant, then it's equally unclear how <noscript> will be parsed
bc75c2548b71aed454f81ac6897bd078 (03:04): is there a list of elements categorized by block/inline level?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:06): don't think so
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:12): How does the HTML5 table algorithm prevent a <th scope="rowgroup"> from being part of a <th scope=col">?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:19): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: i don't understand the question

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:21): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: here's an example from something I'm working on. First a simple table with rows and cols: http://uk.biz.yahoo.com/16/index.html
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:21): 2nd the same thing, but organized into rowgroups http://uk.biz.yahoo.com/16/sector.html
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:21): now in the first instance, scope="col" for the top headers works for all the row headers
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:22): but this can't work in the second instance since the sectors are in that column as per HTML4 spec
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:24): i still don't understand the problem

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:26): i wonder if it's possible to implement the html5 table algorithm with JS, so that when you hover a data cell, its header cells are highlighted, and when you hover a table cell, its data cells are highlighted
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:26): that would be really useful
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:27): s/table cell/header cell/

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:27): Hmm. Well if I understand the HTML4 spec correctly, the sector th's are in the first column. Therefore if you have a th with scope="col" it would technically imply itself to be a header for the sector th's.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:27): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: well, we've got that for headers/ids but not for scope yet
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:27): (Firefox Accessibility Extension)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:28): it is rather useful :)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:28): oh, didn't know about it
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:28): http://firefox.cita.uiuc.edu/ ... that one, get the beta version. Navigation menu, Data tables.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:28): dunno why scope doesn't work with it though
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:29): maybe firefox ignores it
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:29): not sure
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:29): or maybe it's because it's primarily a testing tool and only secondarily a user tool
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:30): maybe firefox ignores both of headers and scope, but headers is easier to implement with the extension
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:32): Actually I guess since it will be using the DOM, what FF does with headers and scope is irrelevant.
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:32): yeah
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:35): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: does the HTML5 table algorithm allow headers to have headers?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:36): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: If it doesn't, then that's even more problematic. Seeing as in real tables, headers often have headers.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:36): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: i agree the draft seems unclear on that point ... i was wondering it myself
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:36): if HTML5 doesn't allow th to have headers than the attrib should be non-conforming for th
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:36): what attribute?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:37): HTML4 clearly does allow th to have headers
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:37): "clearly"?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:37): oh wait... yeah good point it can't do it by disallowing headers since it doesn't have headers
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:37): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: well yeah ... both th and td have headers attribute
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:38): they could easily have made the headers attrib non-conforming for th
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:38): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: right. it was more convenient to write the DTD in that way... :P
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:38): doesn't think html4 is clear about this at all
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:38): or anything for that matter
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:39): Hmm. I can't really believe that including headers attribute for th was for shortening the length of DTD.
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:39): i don't know the rationale
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:40): interesting the example in 11.4.1 shows use of the scope attrib with td

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:40): the spec explains: "Although the first cell in each row contains data, not header information, the scope attribute makes the data cell behave like a row header cell. This allows speech synthesizers to provide the relevant course name upon request or to state it immediately before each cell's content."
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (03:41): yeah, not sure if having cells act as both data cells and header cells is a good thing or not
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:41): I guess the important thing is to devise ways of clearly expressing relationships between data.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (03:42): and not let the header/non-header thing devolve into an even more presentational distinction
